tagDescription: Colonial Office 163. Japanese question: pressure from B.C....Mr. King's return & compilation of report - Evasion by Japan of Treaty regulations...Japanesing the Pacific.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 44. Salvation Army Colonies - Colonial Conference & Standing Commission - Sir W.L.'s views -
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 26. re case of Agnes G. Donahoe'...a suggestion or a Man-of-War
Colonial Office 116. Enclosing copies of Root's & Bond's letters - Invitation to Philadelphia Labrador Boundary
Colonial Office 241. West Indian Commissionchange in tariffBoundary Waters TreatyPublishing of Treaties before ratificationCreation of External Affairs Dept. re amending Bill creating same
Colonial Office 165. Salvation Army: think Govt. did wrong to check British immigration to Canada. Salvation Army chartered 10 steamers for 1908.

Colonial Office 153. Report on Anti Asiatic attitude of B.C. Prohibit landing of Hindus with less than $200 in their possession. Group of Americans fanning flames of Anti Asiatic prejudice...Sir W.L. anxious to give assurance to people of B.C. that measures have been taken to regulate Asiatic inflow into Canada. Hostility does not include Chinese.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 75. Renewal of Elgin - Grey correspondence - re postal rates - Dunfermline -
Colonial Office 197. Difficulties in way of assimilating French & EnglishSensitiveness of conquered racenecessary to emphasize Champlain incidentre speeches at Champlain ceremony
Colonial Office 199. Honours - Quebec TercentenaryMr. CloustonSir W.L.Sir G. DrummondH.E.

Colonial Office 167. Hansard debate on Canadian relations with Japan. Govt. of Japan have made solemn assurance to limit immigration of laborers to Canada to 400. Policy of Opposition hostility to Japanese - policy of Sir W.L. friendly legislation with aid of Japan.

Colonial Office 185. Congratulations on 'Garter' ribbon..Despatch from C.O. asking for Periodical reports in form of secret despatches...Quebec Tercentenary...Mr. Bryce's popularity in Washington...Mr. Taft as next President
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 65. re proposed 'Imperial Council' - & desp. of 20 April 05 - Joint Commission - re Sir F. Pollock
Colonial Office 257a.

Colonial Office 258. Address to Woman's Canadian Club at Quebec. re D. of Connaught being next G.G....Naval Debate...French attitude...suggests Lord C. writing a personal note to Mr. Brodeur on his illness
Colonial Office 188. Sir C. Fitzpatrick's claim to P.C. Mr. CloustonDr. KingHugh Graham
Colonial Office 84. Trade with Orient - Sir Wilfrid's speech - C.P.R. Pacific subsidy - & general question of fast Canadian Atlantic & Pacific service -
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 45. re Colonial Conference - 'Agnes Donahoe' case

Colonial Office 154. Thompson Seton anxious to encourage Yak in Canada. Sir W.L. desires Seton to make official report suggesting where game sanctuaries should be reserved in North West...$5000 given to Dr. Grenfell for reindeer experiment in Labrador...Order in Council for Exceptional Use of 10 million dollars by Government...Necessity of moving crop before closing of Lakes demands this - also shortage of currency...Committee will take charge of arrangements & loan money to principal banks, which money only to be used for crop-moving purposes, banks to pay 6 per cent per annum for a loan of three months and 7 per cent for longer terms...Sending official report on Saskatchewan crops
Colonial Office 179. H.R.H.'s visit made as little irksome as possible. Secret Despatch re General Arbitration Treaty
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 28a. re looking after Canadians in England

Colonial Office 187. Biltmore & Forestry...Conference at Washington of Governors of States to consider conservation of natural forcesQuebec Tercentenary...Lord Crewe to speak at Mansion House...Programme for Quebec...Civil Service Commission...Mr. Foster's speech
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 58. re Dundonald
Colonial Office 222. Congratulating him on success of Treaty negociations

Colonial Office 176. Second reading of Bill appointing Battlefields Commission...Ontario to contribute $100,000 to Quebec celebrations Sir W.L. objects to insertion of clause in bill empowering the U.K. of any self-governing Dominion which gives $100,000 to appoint a representative on the Battlefields Commission. . .Marine & Fisheries laxity...S. African appointment of a Commissioner...U.K. Treasury & Wolfe's claim for unpaid services...Suggested presence of Indian Princes at Quebec
Colonial Office 206. H.R.H. keen about QuebecHonourslist cut downMr. Bryce & Canadian Foreign Deptwould independent action be taken which would interfere with F.O.?

Colonial Office 224. Newfoundland: Mr. Crowe's interview with H.E....Bond & Confederation...University Magazine & article on P.E.I....Nfld. Tariff...Inter Imperial Free Trade - Washington Conference Natural Resources...Military Training in Schools
Colonial Office 198. Honours: Govt. representative for QuebecCanadian - U.S. questionsSir W.L.'s view on F. Gerring case not tenable

Colonial Office 119. Philadelphia invitation - H.E. speech at Canadian Club Toronto - criticisms re cheap labour in B.C. - 'cheap' labour should be treated 'with caution & reserve- Re contributions to the Navy - Australian position - Root's visit and 'cleaning the slate - re Bryce coming to Ottawa - Marquis Doria & the Canadian Govt.
Colonial Office 236. Extension of term of G.G. to six yearssuggests visiting London June to consulut C.O.
Colonial Office 132. Salvation Armyimmigration to Canada & S. Africa
Colonial Office 195. Representative of U.K. for Quebec
Colonial Office 219. re Honour for Mr. FieldingMr. King's visit to England re Asiatic question.
Colonial Office 173. Mr. Bryce in OttawaSir W.L. to appoint a Battlefields Commission - Presence at Quebec of leading representatives of Self-Governing Colonies
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 48. Sir S. Fleming - Toronto speech - Colonial Conference & Commission proposal - Canada can control her own representative - etc.

Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 27. Autonomy Bill - Imperial obligations or Canada - England to Australia via Canada - Fast Atlantic Service - Mail contracts - Imperial postage on Newspapers - Salvation Army Colonies
Colonial Office 217. Electionre Honour for Mr. Fieldingdifficulties of P.C., value of which seldom realised in Colonies
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 31. Saying that arrangements have been made re notification of Canadians going home.
Colonial Office 117. Root still expected here in January - Convention of 1818 - Cleaning the Slate - re liberty 'in common' - Bryce should not go to Washington via Ottawa.
Colonial Office 250. Return to OttawaWill send Despatch giving account of trip west
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 28. Reorganization of Militia  District commands - re Halifax & good feeling between Regulars & Militia - Autonomy Bill - Bourassa - Nelson Centenary
Colonial Office 249. Gen. French to go on Inspection Tour in CanadaDefence Conferencesuggested amalgamation of Canada's 2 Defence DepartmentsDelay in Boundary Waters settlement
Colonial Office 88. Re date of Colonial Conference
Colonial Office 231. Waterways Treaty - difficulty of keeping Press ignorant of negociations before completedenclosing copy of Despatch to F.O. from Washington -

Colonial Office 191. Think Sir W.L. is marking time on outstanding questions...Attitude of U.S. overbearing & insolent...local interests always override general principles...General election probable before November...Quebec Programme...French...Duke or Norfolk...Provinces support Quebec Tercentenary

Colonial Office 115. Toronto speech - cheap labour  open door of Orient - Coal strike & settlement Budget speech - intermediate tariff  Sir W. Laurier & the ratification of the Bond-Hay Treaty - Sir Wilfrid will expect U.S. to do as much for Canada etc.
Colonial Office 202. Three RiversLaval speechesabsence of English tuition in French country schools in Quebecinfluence of church

Colonial Office 264. Subjects for discussion at 1911 Conference. Separation of S.G.D.s & Colonies in Home Dept...Application of a Lemieux Act to International Disputes: Financial boycott of any Power which rushes into war without first having submitted cause of dispute to Hague Tribunal - Sir Edgar Speyer...

Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 60. Visit of Cruises Squadron - Prince Louis - Stephen Lyttelton - Hanbury - Montreal arrangements re bluejackets - Ottawa & correspondence with Sir W.L. re bluejackets - Colonial Conference

Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 73. Congratulation etc. - write freely - English postal rates to Canada - Carnegie Dunfermline College - Carnegie's opinion of Lord Elgin - Earl Elgin & Earl Grey again connected in reverssed positions
Colonial Office 167a.
Colonial Office 168. re Lord Alberstone's visit to U.S. feeling of hostility in Canada against him

Colonial Office 149. Sir W.L.'s opinion re Bond's action most satisfactory to C.O. also memo. of Mr. Aylesworth...Confident that when Canada & Newfoundland differ, the other Premiers (as appealed to by Bond) will have no hesitation as to which side they agree with - Most desirable that Canada should take the lead in preparing terms of Reference to Hague, at that promptly. Difficulty of Indian question re immigration...Doubt as to expediency of All Red Route

Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 56. Work of Session - Autonomy Bill Members indemnity - Ministers pensions. Flag incident - Colonial Conference etc.- Sir W.L. views  Inspector Hughes - outlining Maritime Tour
Colonial Office 180. Lord Elgin's inability to come to Canada for the Quebec Tercentenary.

Colonial Office 181. Asiatic Exclusion League on Pacific Coast...Secret agent of Canadian Govt...Japanese regulations...Passports issued before the Lemieux settlement, but not used, must be included in the 400 fixed as limit...American Fleet in Pacific...Sir W.L. does not like idea & will not send invitation to visit B.C. People however are pressing him...American Fleet visiting Japan: difficult to avoid extending them invitation to visit B.C. Mr. Bryce's visit - difficulty in negotiating affairs because of lack of External Affairs Department...Marine & Fisheries Dept. - Civil Service Commission Report - Sifton & All Red Route
Colonial Office 243. Honest exaggeration of Canada - re continuance of H.E. as G.G. till 1910
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 43. Agnes Donahoe case - Transvaal Constitution - Colonial Conference -

Colonial Office 122. Mr. Root's visit - no chance of immediate settlement - Some arrangements may become to re free admission of coal etc. & minor points which do not involve controversy with regard to national rights
Colonial Office 207. Custody of secret military documents by Military Secretary to Governors General
Colonial Office 139. Sir W.L. thinks Vancouver troubles much exaggerated...Japanese Govt. will assist by keeping number of immigrants restricted

Colonial Office 223. Mr. King's visit to the East a good thing - problem of relationship between white parts of Empire & the rest...What is the principle which forbids a Sikh to go to B.C. or a Singalese to go to Durban or Queensland? Inter Departmental Committee appointed at India Office to go into whole question. Waterways Treaty: Mr. Bryce impressed with necessity of acting with Root while latter has influence with Senate. Fisheries: Dangerous to press Colonies to accept what they dislike.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 59. 'Lecture Scheme' - re slides etc. - re party tactics at home - re Dundonald - re Newfoundland & Confederation
Colonial Office 146. re official communications from Sir W.L. Forwarding copy of University Magazine with article on 'Ashburton Treaty' & The Patience of England'
Colonial Office 234. Naval position: University Magazine re Canadian Naval cadets at OsborneBritish Diplomacy & Canada - correcting old view that Britain sacrified Canadian interests to U.S.
Colonial Office 129. re Marquis of Doria

Colonial Office 160. Newfoundland: Sir Robert Reid thinks Bond is finished & will do nothing re Terms of Reference. Sir E. Morris appealing to people, & Bond's candidate anticipates defeat...Attorney General afraid of his seat - financial & railway troubles maturing: Bond becoming unpopular. Desirable to bring to an end position which makes H.M. Govt. override Nfld. Interference by H.M. Govt. resented...Possibility when Treaty rights of American fishermen defined by Hague, that Canada will cry out for the restriction of American fishermen to their Treaty rights, & for withdrawing privileges at present enjoyed. Feel happier if U.S. Senate would ratify free fish for free fishing arrangement. President's message re removal of duties on pulp. Attitude of Sir W.L. towards U.S. always friendly
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 49. Mr. L.'s Canada Club speech - Canadian press (London)
Colonial Office 244. Despatch re Mr. Preston's conduct in Tokio
Colonial Office 256a. Behring Sea
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 35. Nelson's Centenary & Mayor or Montreal...Enclosing copy of letter to the King (3 May 05)
Colonial Office 196. Safe guarding Prince during Quebec Tercentenary
Colonial Office 246. Imperial Press ConferenceInadequacy of present system of Press communication

Colonial Office 147. Aylesworth's opinion on Bonds protest against Home Govt. Sir W.L. instructs Aylesworth to draft Terms of Reference to Hague...Everything has been done by Sir. W.L. to smooth Bond's ruffled feelings

Colonial Office 218. Quebec Province at once the strength & weakness of Canadian Imperialism - self respect growing in Canada...superiority over Americans...Free Trade between the Empire & U.S....Tejâ Singh...Col. Swayne confident of persuading Hindus to go to B. Honduras...Trade with West IndiesMcKenzie King to go to China via India...Sir W.L.'s views on Preference  Results of Election...

Colonial Office 121. re Mr. Root's visit -'free fish for free fishing -sacrificing national rights would be dangerous - feeling against settlement is growing - Fisheries debate re withdrawal of Modus vivendi - Re arbitration on matter of Treaty rights - American claim re treaty of 1818 should not be tolerated - is a new claim - No distinction has ever been made between British subjects & U.S. citizens in framing regulations governing territorial waters.
Colonial Office 215. Correspondence re Mr. Oliver's speech at Nelson on Hindus
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 19. re Jones - Addresses & replies  Debate on Address - Rider Haggard

Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 11a. (enclosing letter to Lord Selborne re Canadian Naval Programme)...re loan of Lake - Ontario election - Moral tone of politics higher than before - Moral standards at home

Colonial Office 130. Arbitration as means of settling differences between Canada & U.S. - Sir W.L. co-operate with C.O. bringing pressure upon Sir R. Bonds. Readiness to meet Root weakening on Canadian side - re free fish...Sir W.L. leaving to attend Conference in London...Col. H.N. going to London...

Colonial Office 177. Prince's consent at Admiraltys willingness to send Fleet...Sir F. Hopwood suggested to accompany Prince. Telegram from Newfoundland saying there should be no delay about Terms of Reference. Illness of C.B.
Colonial Office 141. Enclosing correspondence with Sir W.L....re approval of F.O. of action by Canada on Japanese question, no time for direct communication between Canada & F.O.
Colonial Office 127. Postage on Newspaper matter - re reduction in rate etc.

Colonial Office 148. Request of Germany that Canada should exten same advantages to them as are extended to France under Treaty...Interviews between German Consul & Mr. Fielding...Germany willing to give Canada advantages of her minimum tariff on certain articles. Mr. Fielding anxious to arrive at a settlement on this question before publication of New French Treaty. West Indian exports not affected by new arrangement
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 47. Quebec reception - Salmon fishing - Shooting in N.W. - re scene in H. of C.
Colonial Office 131. re unwillingness of Sir W.L. to accept invitations in London
Colonial Office 245. Sir W.L.'s attitude on DefenceDesirability of establishing Branches of Canadian Navy League, specially in QuebecBoundaries Waters TreatySir W.L. still dissatisfied

Colonial Office 240. H.E.'s acceptance of another yearImperial Defence, affairs in S. AfricaNavyNewfoundlandSir R. Williams to succeed Sir W. MacgregorSir W.L.'s view of a division of C.O. & an Imperial Council
Colonial Office 190. H.R.H. Keen about visit to Quebec...Session last till Aug. therefore impossible Lord Crewe come to Canada...C.S. Commission
Colonial Office 174. Mr. Bryce's visit most usefulDelay in bringing forward resolution by Sir W.L. re Quebec
Colonial Office 96. Mr. Root's speech at Pilgrim's dinner - Fitzpatrick's resignation - Honours - departmental scandals

Colonial Office 226. Boundary Waters Treaty: Final step still to be taken, but Treaty safe...Mr. Gibbons to explain to Canadian Club meaning of Treaty...External Affairs Dept....Suggests all London Offices of Self Governing Colonies being under one roof...Suggestions for Imperial Conference Asiatic question - Conference between white & asiatic powers
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 57. Donahue case - don't understand reference to Sir. W.L.'s attitude etc.
Colonial Office 95. Canadian-German tariff negotiations - re desirability of visiting Newfoundland - re confederation - Howley strong for it
Colonial Office 128. Re Transvaal Govt. - Botha - Fitzpatrick - Canadian analogy - Salvation Army & Trades Unions
Colonial Office 94. Outstanding questions Canada & U.S.A. - Root accepts invitation to visit Ottawa - re Canadian attaché at Washington - Carnegie's visit
Colonial Office 172. Quebec TercentenaryPresence of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales - Fleet - precedence President Roosevelt's interview with Mr. King - discussion in H. of L. on treatment of Asiatics.
Colonial Office 242. HonoursDifficulties of creating C.B.sIf Knighthood not acceptable to Mr. Scott no hope of K.C.M.G.
Colonial Office 140. Sir Charles Tupper's attitude on B.C. situation

Colonial Office 208. Quebec Tercentenary...Birthday Honours...Australia's list longer than Canada's...comparison between the two...growing irritation in Canada may resolve itself into direct request from G.G. to King for Honours recommended by Prime Minister...quâ establishment of automatic rule for Honours...K.C.M.G.'sMr. Clouston...Gen. Otter...Canadian Foreign Dept...reform urgently needed...Prorogation of Parliament...
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 74. Halifax & Esquimalt - organization of Colonial Conferences - Garvin & Mr. Lyttelton's proposals re Conference - Balfour & Chamberlain -
Colonial Office 77. Title of 'Her Excellency'  Campbell's poem

Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 15. Garrison question...Birth or Twin Provinces...re date of taking Halifax over...British postal rates on periodicals etc. etc. (Sir G.D.'s speech)...re Walker's memo...etc.
Colonial Office 133. Publication of Despatch re meat inspection
Colonial Office 152. Wishes to give a picture of his Father to Canadian collection of G.G.'s Lord Morley's view on Hindu question - passports, as less of two evils

Colonial Office 235. Boundary Waters Treaty en l'air...Michigan resolution opposed by Sir W.L...Sir W.L.'s views on Crown Colonies & Self Governing Colonies being separately housed...Thinks question of all London Agencies being under one roof will naturally come up for consideration...Hostile to Secretariat as suggested by Sir F. Pollock...Housing of all London Agencies under one roof not necessarily an advance towards Imperial Council
Colonial Office 78. Judicial Committee of P.C. and suggestion of Mr. Blake's appt.

Colonial Office 186. Points for speeches at Quebec Tercentenary...Prince of Wales might have come...Lord Elgin intrigued out of C.O....re message from the King to be telegraphed during Quebec Tercentenary

Colonial Office 230. Newspaper Comments on Naval position...Sir W.L. recognizes weakness of his Marine policy, & need for various administration. Boundary Waters Treaty: U.S. Govt. having purchased riparian rights obstacle to Treaty removed...Treaty is for 5 years...risks in accepting Treaty therefore not great. Newfoundland: pressing Sir W.M. for preparation of case for Hague...Sir Robert Finlay suggested for Newfoundland counsel

Colonial Office 97. re 'cleaning the slate' - Durand not hopeful - re invitation to King to visit Canada - question of going to U.S. also - Re Nfld. & Confederation - no objection to H.E. visiting Nfld. - Colonial Conference, India to be represented.
Colonial Office 259. Forwarding report of Naval DebateMr. Borden disappointing in his abandonment of strong position
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 18. North West Autonomy...Separate Schools - Mr. Siftons resignation
Colonial Office 184. Retirement of Lord Elgin from the Colonial Office
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 29. re De Celles & Le Bouton Rouge

Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 53. Fishing - Laurier & Colonial Conference proposals - Senator David's sketch of Sir Wilfrid - Turgeon's visit to England - Dundonald's attack on Sir F. Borden - & re desp. asked for.
Colonial Office 93. re his proposed visit - reduction of postal rates - mail subsidies - etc.
Colonial Office 116a. Pennsylvania University - 'Cleaning the Slate - Bond-Hay Treaty'  proposed ratification of - Root's letter of 30 June Newfoundland Fisheries - Hindoos in B.C.
Colonial Office 251. B.W.T. report on St. Mary & Milk Rivers irrigation
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 41. re Imperial Council & Colonial Conference - Sir W.L.'s views -
Colonial Office 189. Enclosing copy of letter to Mr. Bryce
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 63. Mr. Jebb's Colonial Nationalism, Chapter 3 - re Alaska - as to Review & correction of certain statements

Colonial Office 134. Cables re postal rates - Incomprehensible that Britain should refuse to consider Canadian proposals...Mr. Bryce in Ottawa - surprised at common belief of Canadians that U.K. has always sacrificed Canadian interests in dealing with U.S....Appointment of historical scientists to investigate facts re Ashburton Treaty, Alaska Boundary etc. etc.
Colonial Office 92. re 'cleaning the slate' - Canadian attaché - C.P.R. Pacific subsidy to be cotinued for 2 years - re Country 'Elgin' challenge cup
Colonial Office 256b. Duke of Connaught
Colonial Office 182. National Battlefields Commission gazetted..re vacating of house by Sir L. Jetté for Prince of Wales

Colonial Office 233. Mr. Stead's publication of private letter..Naval position...Sir W.L. aggrieved at reception of his speech...Mr. Foster's eloquence...Admiral Kingsmill not consulted on naval policy...weakness of M. Brodeur...H.E. visits New York...President Eliot refuses London
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 46. Canadian Manufacturers & The King - Canada & Japan -

Colonial Office 90. re Canadian attaché at Washington - re temporary appt. for special purposes - viz 'cleaning the slate' - Hopeful that negotiations between Canada & U.S. may be successful - Pilgrim's dinner great success etc. - encloses speeches - Root going to S. America in July - General belief in States that Nov. elections will favour Democrats - so it is important to 'clean the slate' quickly.
Colonial Office 76. Work of Agricultural College - Guelph - Sask. & Alberta Elections - Haultain - General prosperity - Tariff - Hewins - 'Newfoundland Bays' - 'headland to headland' doctrine

Colonial Office 257. Rumours of D. of Connaught succeeding H.E. in Canada...re Sir Charles Rivers Wilson being further 'honoured'...Thanks Quebec Commission for medal...Times considers Mr. Willison the ablest journalist in Colonial Empire...discussed with him Canadian Navy...
Colonial Office 171. Visit of 4 Canadian M.P. s to Washingtoninterview with President - who repeated to them a speech he made at the Gridiron Club - re Japanese & U.S.
Colonial Office 248. re recall of Mr. Preston from Tokio
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 72. re New Canadian Tariff - Hewins, Fielding & British preference - General Election - Garvin's article in Empire & Century
Colonial Office 118. re St. Pierre & Miquelon

Colonial Office 124. Root's visit - Enclosing his speech at Canadian Club - Can. (?) H. of C. & Modus vivendi debate - Root now understands Sir W. Laurier's position - had not even been aware of existence of Modus vivendi! - U.S. profoundly indifferent to outside matters & hence influence of Gloucester fleet very great. Held out no likelihood of Senate admitting Newfoundland or Canadian fish - Fisheries debate - If U.S. make no move with view to settlement there may be agitation to do away with modus vivendi - U.S. might retaliate by withdrawing bonding privileges. Sir Wilfrid will not be in hurry to precipitate matters. Root's speech very favourably commented on in Canada
Colonial Office 82. re proposed visit to Tuskegee -
Colonial Office 204. re obtaining advance copies of speeches of American & French representatives at Quebec

Colonial Office 125. Newfoundland & U.S. fishery question - Sir Wilfrid thinks H.M.G. would 'make a great mistakein preventing Bond making new attempt to secure ratification of his Convention - Sir W.L. does not believe Senate will ratify - Root understands Canadian situation & knows sentiment has much changed as regards U.S.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 37. Sir Sandford Fleming & the All Red Cable - & re publication of H.E. desp. on subject
Colonial Office 166. re Joint Commission & Treaty on Waterways
Colonial Office 145a. Canadian Tariff
Colonial Office 214. Letter to Mr. McBride about B.C. election contest
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 32. re Roll of HonourAutonomy Bill
Colonial Office 221. Treaty acceptedoutspoken manner of Gibbons more successful than deferential attitude of British Ambassador
Colonial Office 80. Pilgrims Dinner - restoration of Franklin picture - Choate's visit - re settlement of outstanding questions between Canada & U.S.
Colonial Office 162. Launching of Battlefields Scheme...Invitation to Premiers & Leaders of opposition of self-governing Colonies to become Vice Patrons.
Colonial Office 107. Outstanding questions Canada & U.S. - Anxious to know line taken by Canadian Ministers

Colonial Office 126. Re relations between U.S. & B.N.A. - Sir Wilfrid's remarks in House - Canada's sympathy with Newfoundland -'No more Alverstone capitalations' - Fear that H.M.G. may be tempted to cultivate U.S. at expense of B.N.A. Relations between Great & Greater Britain - Sam Hughes debate
Colonial Office 261. Last obstacle in way of Boundary Waters Treaty removed
Colonial Office 135. HonoursSir C. Fitzpatrick
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 20. (?)...Autonomy Bill crisis - correspondence
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 66. re Deakin's address on Imperial Federation - & Jebb's articles on 'Imperial Organization' Sir Wilfrid's views on above
Colonial Office 263. re Rush Bagot Treaty...Forces in favour of disarmament steadily growing...Miss Laut...Pinchot...policy to mark time...re Federation of U.K.

Colonial Office 164. Newfoundland: Sir W.L. declining to move before Nfld. disappointing - Home Govt. propose to draft statement for submission to Canada & Nfld, but would prefer it to come from this side, because of misunderstanding. Continue to press Bond for his draft, but without result...Would the Indians have left India if they had not received encouragement from Canada?...re Honour for Mr. Clouston - K.C.M.G. when Knighthood refused is to process of forcing hand of H.M.G.

Colonial Office 156. Canada's attitude re compensation of Chinese affected during riots. If Japs receive exceptional treatment Chinese also should be included. Suggestion that proceeds of Chinese Importation Tax be allocated to bringing in agricultural settlers to B.C.
Colonial Office 91. Re Blake & Judicial Committee of P.C. - no chance

Colonial Office 138. Flight of 700 Indian: from American to Canadian soil  Feeling in B.C. against Asiatics as strong as further south...Japanese evade passport regulations by going to Honolulu & thence to Canada...Sir W.L. suggests deporting Japanese who come from Honolulu...Honours: Dr. Coulter, C.J. of Ont. C.J. of Quebec, Mr. Clouston...Sir Chas. Tupper

Colonial Office 87. C.P.R. steamship subsify - Canadian provincial gaols - Canadian attaché at Embassy - F.O. opposed - suspicious could be cleared away via the Governor- General - claims against U.S. - Tuskegee visit - Parliamentary Return as to Imperial money spent on British possessions Beyond the Seas -

Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 12. (enclosing letter to Sir J. Colomb re Canada & her duty to the Empire in the matter of defence etc.) re British postal rates on papers, magazines etc. - Canadian Associated Press desps. - withhold letter to Selborne re Sir E. Seymour

Colonial Office 151. King's Birthday...Prayer for the King - offered up by Ben Greet Players - old Elizabethan custom...Bond wishes to go his own way, unassisted by Canada...Hindu question - panic subsided in B.C. but arrival of fresh immigrants likely to rouse people again...Question of sending more frequent confidential despatches to C.O.

Colonial Office 113. re Newfoundland visit - re Sir W. MacGregor's financial position etc. - Bond & the fishery question - re Confederation - re boycotting Japanese in B.C. - Mackenzie King - & labour misrepresentations
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 24. re Autonomy crisis...Clippings - Haultain's letter etc. etc. - Religious feeling
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 23. re Autonomy crisisre Fitzpatrick& general outline of situation
Colonial Office 89. re Ministers negotiating privately with German Consul re tariff matters - Sir W.L. informed that H.M.G. expect to be kept informed etc.
Colonial Office 120. re Root's visit - re Mr. Root's quotation from Lord Salisbury's letter of 3 April 1880.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 11b. re H.M.G. views as to defence of Halifax and Esquimalt
Colonial Office 193. Sorry to leave C.O...Lord Dudleys presence at Quebec...Lord Brucepicture of Lord Elgin's Father for Gallery
Colonial Office 200. P.C. for H.E.Honours at Quebec CelebrationIrish AmericanChamplain incident
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 13. re Halifax & Esquimalt - Lake's promotion - re Postal rate on Magazines & papers - re Joint High Commission - re British Preference & Sir Wilfrid's views.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 71. re visit of Prince Arthur as guest of Dominion - Govt.

Colonial Office 212. Arbitration Reference...Sir W.L. presses for agreement...Newcombe's report...Sir W.L. desires to do nothing which will supply Newfoundland with a grievance...therefore cannot accept two sets of questions
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 50. Mr. L.'s Canada Club speech - enclosing French Translation etc. - Honours case of Cox - visit of Inspector General (H.R.H.)
Colonial Office 248a. re Duke of Connaught
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 69. re Imperial 'Council'

Colonial Office 144. Direct correspondence between Colonies & F.O. must increase complications - Course adopted re Sir W.L.'s letter to Sir C. Macdonald, quite rightAsks for something on which to open negotiations with India Office re hostility of B.C. to Hindus...Is reason that they underbid whites, main objection?
Colonial Office 142. re making Sir Charles Tupper a P.C.

Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 67. Desp. of April 20th - Imperial Council - Minute of Council on subject - disabused Sir W.L.'s mind re Pollock being supposed agent of Mr. Lyttelton - Enclosed Sir Sandford Fleming's letter on Pollock's scheme - Danger in enforcing pace unduly - etc.
Colonial Office 261. D. of Connaught probable sucessor to H.E..Waships on Lakesasks for Canada's opinion -
Colonial Office 112. Visit to B.C. - importance of trade with Orient - also of Fruit growing - Labour in B.C. controlled from the U.S. - Profit in fruit farming in B.C.

Colonial Office 183. H.E. leaves for Bermuda...Newfoundland Terms of Reference arrive at Ottawa - copies having been sent at least a week before to Mr. Bryce & C.O. Hindus - Order in Council - Vancouver Court decides that officers of Govt. cannot legally enforce O. in C. Mr. Oliver thinks transportation companies may take advantage of this decision, & bring in Hindus & Japs from Honolulu & Hong Kong. To provide against this a bill giving statutory status to O. in C. will be passed...Danger in B.C. arises from C.P.R. having advertised in India for labour - & from Indian agitators desirous of promoting sedition

Colonial Office 238. Hague ConferenceBill to legislate for the EmpireO. in C. to be reserved for consideration of each Govt.

Colonial Office 175. Mr. King's mission to England on Asiatic Immigration etc. Sir W.L. regrets having to deport Hindus to Hong Kong, on arrival at Vancouver: realising embarrassment to Govt. of India, but he also realizes seriousness of result or attack on Hindus by rioters in B.C...Mr. Root emphasizes President's anxiety re Japan saying that Peace depended upon Japan taking a sane view. U.S. will not be trifled with if Japan eludes Treaty regulations

Colonial Office 136. re Report of Marine Dept. 1890 on 'purse seines'...Use of purse seines illegal in Canadian Territorial waters, since 1891...Trap nets prohibited unless special license obtained...American fishermen equal rights with Canadian so long as license is obtained.

Colonial Office 158. re picture of Lord Elgin for collectionCopy of Grant picture is what is wanted

Colonial Office 161. B.C. position - Cabinet decides that proposals recommended by Lemieux & Sir C. Fisheries Arbitration & Boundary Waters Treaty...Change of attitude in Sir W.L. re Imperial Council...In 1907 he accepted Secretariat on understanding that it would be under ministerial responsibility of Secretary of State for Colonies...New suggest appointment of two ministers in place of Colonial Secretary, & housing under one roof all London Agencies, i.e. creation of Imperial Council
